text: The first time that Ghana was at the Olympic Games was in 1952. The International Olympic Committee's official abbreviation for Ghana is GHA. "Official abbreviations" at The Games of the XVIII Olympiad, Tokyo, 1964, [p. 9 of 409 PDF]; retrieved 2012-10-12. ==History== Ghana was known by the colonial name of Gold Coast. The nation has been in most Summer Olympic Games since then, missing the 1956 Summer Olympics, boycotting the 1976 Games and the 1980 Summer Olympics. Ghana was at the 2010 Winter Olympics. The National Olympic Committee for Ghana was formed in 1952 and recognized by the International Olympic Committee that same year. ==List of medalists== Medal Name Games Sport Event Clement Quartey 1960 Rome Boxing Men's light welterweight Eddie Blay 1964 Tokyo Boxing Men's light welterweight Prince Amartey 1972 Munich Boxing Men's middleweight Joachin Yaw Acheampong, Simon Addo, Sammi Adjei, Frank Amankwah, Bernard Aryee, Isaac Asare, Kwame Ayew, Ibrahim Dossey, Mohammed Gargo, Samuel Kumah, Nii Lamptey, Yaw Preko, Shamo Quaye 1992 Barcelona Football Men's competition ==Related pages== * List of IOC country codes == References == ==Other websites == * Ghana at Olympic.org * Ghana profile at London2012.com Category:Sport in Ghana Category:Nations at the Olympics Category:National sports teams of Ghana
